@TheViewFromLL2 Yep, and I completely agree with you (again) that this is a huge problem. Only solution is divestment (or: not being prez).
@TheViewFromLL2 Bottom line: list doesn't look strange if you're in the business of U.S. foreign policy. That may just be good luck, though.
@TheViewFromLL2 My point is that a) you're right that this admin doesn't deserve benefit of doubt & b) still could be nothing to it at all.
@TheViewFromLL2 It's also a list of countries for whom bilateral relationship with US is extremely important. IOW: could be coincidence.
@TheViewFromLL2 ...associated with DJT so I'm not going to keep quibbling on this, because ultimately we need MORE scrutiny than less (2)
@TheViewFromLL2 It's impossible to give context to make you appreciate how deeply I agree w/ you about impropriety of nearly EVERYTHING (1)
@TheViewFromLL2 (PS completely unrelated but I'm a huge fan of the work you, @EvidenceProf, & @rabiasquared do. Each of you is a real hero.)
@TheViewFromLL2 That's a problem he created for himself and that he's responsible for solving, for sure. But the call sheet isn't weird.
@TheViewFromLL2 Without divesting himself from business interests, there's basically no way to assure public that his behavior is correct.
@TheViewFromLL2 That list looks very much like what I would expect from first 31 calls any new PEOTUS would take. His business is the prob.
@TheViewFromLL2 To be clear, I'm not saying there's no impropriety. I'm just saying it can't be discerned from the list of countries alone.
